captions.text:
Good morning Hank, it's Friday, and my time
in the Netherlands is almost coming to an

end, sadly. There is so much that I will miss
about Amsterdam: I will miss the elm trees

and the amazing public transportation and
my little slivery view of the canal. I'll

miss the cafés and the bicyclic abundance
and living in an apartment that is older than

my country - and those are just the things
that I will miss that I can see outside my
window!

By the way, Hank, if you hear any background
noise, that's mom. Say hi, mom!

Mother Green: Hey darling. Your mother misses
you.

John: Your mother misses you. She'll come
all the way to Amsterdam to visit me, but

you don't see her in Montana very often. I
don't know who the favorite son is!

Right, Hank, so a couple notes about your
last video: first off, your punishments are

very mean, and I will talk more about that
when I get back to the States; secondly, when

you had that ice cream truck and it was playing
"Sexy Back", it reminded me of the one thing

that I won't miss about Amsterdam, and that
is the soundtrack in the stores.

So Hank, you know how, when you're shopping
for stuff, they generally pipe music in so

that you're happy and you want to purchase
goods and services? Right, but when they do

that here, they don't use muzak, they use
real music, which is great. But they also

use a lot of gangster rap, and they don't,
like, edit the lyrics. So basically, your

experience of buying baby wipes and/or shoes
is like this--I'm going to replace all the

curse words with the names of British Romantic
poets:

"I'm a William Blake gangster, so of course
you want my Samuel Taylor Coleridge, you're

going to want to be all up IN this William
Wordsworth, like OH Percy Shelley, OH OH Percy

Shelley! I'm the Lord Byron-ing Samuel Taylor
Coleridge, William Blake!"

It's just an unpleasant way to buy diapers,
Hank, so I won't miss that. But I will miss

a lot. I want to thank all the Belgian and
Dutch Nerdfighters who came out to events,

and I also want to thank the Dutch Literature
Foundation for making this possible.

In other news, Hank, I was recently on tour
in Hoogeveen--file under places that seem

made up but aren't--and a Nerdfighter gave
me this "This Star Won't Go Out" bracelet

which I've been wearing ever since because
my "This Star Won't Go Out" bracelet was broken

by a member of my household who will remain
nameless, although he is quite small.

Anyway Hank, the generosity of this present
reminded me to tell you that "This Star Won't

Go Out" bracelets are available at dftba.com.
100% of the proceeds go to benefit This Star

Won't Go Out, a foundation that was established
in memory of Nerdfighter Esther Earl. All

the money from This Star Won't Go Out goes
to support families who've been affected by

cancer. Hank, believe it or not, it's been
almost ten months since Esther died. In that

time, we've raised more than $10,000 for This
Star Won't Go Out, which I think is pretty

awesome. Nerdfighteria, thank you for your
support, and there's a link to get your bracelet
in the doobly-doo.

Also Hank, being on tour in the Netherlands
has reminded me that you and I are going on

tour in the United States when my new, as-yet-untitled,
but soon-to-be-titled book comes out. Nerdfighters,

we really want this tour to be amazing, but
we're also not that creative. For instance,

Hank, did you know that the probable title
of my new novel was stolen from a Nerdfighter?

As, in fact, was the central observation of
the book, so... thanks, Nerdfighteria!

Right, so but we're not that creative, so
we want to know from you, Nerdfighteria, what

you would like to see happen. Don't tell us
where you want us to go; that's a separate

conversation. Just what you would like to
see, what you'd like to do, what should happen.

Also, one last question, Nerdfighteria: would
you like it if I read the audiobook? Uh, it's

a little bit weird because the book is narrated
by a young woman, and I am not a young woman,

so you'll hear my voice being like, "And then
I took off my bra." [laughs] I mean - I don't

- she doesn't take off her bra in the book
that I can remember, but you know, whatever,
like, it might be a little weird.

All right Hank, I've got to go back to editing.
DFTBA, I will see you on Monday - I got the
day right! Nerdfighters!

title: Then I Took Off My Bra

comments.text:
Hey John! Just realized i could have said hi to you in person if I knew you 
existed in 2011, but sadly I learned about your existence in 2013 when my 
school forced me read your book for english (i didn't mind that ), yeah 
your book is used in the dutch education,!,   Hoogeveen is really close to 
my home town and my mom works there and my dad writes about books... but 
that was before you got way to populair as a writer in the Netherlands... 
and its weird knowing that a cool person visited my province and i missed 
it... so if u ever return, i will come say hi and invite you to visit Emmen 
(a 30 min drive from hoogeveen)  i bet Henry would like it cuz my 
town consists of a Zoo, i can see tigers out of my living room window 
(which it kinda sad but also kinda cool) and our penguins escape often and 
then walk into the retirement home (which is build next to it) they going 
to expand and its finished in 2016... i'm sorry about the long comment have 
a nice thursday! bye!﻿

comments.author: Pepâ la Pow

comments.text:
Sadly due to the all nature of globlisation not much in the way of quality 
content gets made in my country anymore owing in large parts to companies 
finding it easier & cheaper to just purchase content from overseas. As the 
US speaks english we end up with a lot of US content here in Australia. So 
I end up having an opinion on it.

I understand that your culture is more prudish but the thing I don't 
understand is why make the content with swearing then just bleep it out? If 
swearing is so bad that it needs to be covered up, why make it with 
swearing in the first place?

I watch as much locally made content as I can because it suits my 
sensibilities better but sadly major corporations think a market of 23 
million isn't worth catering for so continue to buy overseas for much of 
their programing. There is tonnes of UK stuff on air over here too

To be clear I wasn't slagging the US, I just find some of the quirks 
annoying. To be fair I find a lot of Australian quirks annoying too
comments.author: Pepâ la Pow

comments.text:
+Pepâ la Pow Believe it or not, American culture is different from your 
culture. Uptight? Yes, I agree. But for now, it's our reality. Maybe it'll 
change one day.

comments.text: And a lot of times, you can choose between censored and non censored.
comments.author: Pinkpop 1245

comments.text:
I'll let you in on a secret... A lot of TV stations and Record companies 
get complaints from parents because their child heard that and it wasn't 
bleeped out. Complaints are bad for business. They are doing it more now 
because of "modern" parents who feed their children organic food and stuff 
like that. The "modern" parents are extremely over protective.
comments.author: Pinkpop 1245

comments.text:
+Pepâ la Pow I come from a country where words are not censored in songs, 
and I do agree that Americans can sometimes be unnecessarily uptight and it 
can get rather irritating. Censorship has never felt right to me, and I've 
never seen what the big deal is with curse words.
However, I must disagree that TV, movies, and other people shouldn't be 
responsible for raising children. You can't prevent children from being 
influenced by others, no matter how hard you try. You can change how it 
influences them, but you can't change the fact that it does.
comments.author: No Longer Sam Fillip

comments.text:
Why is someone else's offence my problem? If they don't like it they can 
turn it off or not put themselves in the situation where they can hear what 
might offend them?

As for kids, while I don't have kids myself I do have nephews. They're 3 & 
5. They have heard many swear words. If they hear me swear they say "you 
shouldn't say that Aunty Fi". You know why they say that? It's because they 
have been raised properly by their parents. TV, movies & other people 
shouldn't be responsible for raising your children. I'm an adult I like to 
watch things I like without it being censored. I'm able or at least should 
be able to make that choice myself. 

I'm ok with you making the choice not to watch said material but why censor 
it "just in case"?
comments.author: Pepâ la Pow

comments.text:
The reason why they bleep it out is because children could be watching 
accidentally and we don't want children to learn bad words and say them. We 
sometimes leave the first syllable so that adults know which word it is. 
Plus, some words may be offensive to someone or their religion.
